segments.pli: Aṅguttara Nikāya 3
segments.en: Numbered Discourses 3

segments.pli: 13. Kusināravagga
segments.en: 13. Kusināra

segments.pli: 123. Kusinārasutta
segments.en: 123. At Kusināra

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati baliharaṇe vanasaṇḍe.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusināra, in the Forest of Offerings.

segments.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

segments.pli: “bhikkhavo”ti.
segments.en: “Mendicants!”

segments.pli: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
segments.en: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā svātanāya bhattena nimanteti.
segments.en: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.

segments.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti.
segments.en: The mendicant accepts if they want.

segments.pli: So tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamati; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdati.
segments.en: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāreti.
segments.en: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.

segments.pli: Tassa evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: The mendicant thinks:

segments.pli: ‘sādhu vata myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāretī’ti.
segments.en: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods.’

segments.pli: Evampissa hoti:
segments.en: Then they think:

segments.pli: ‘aho vata māyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā āyatimpi evarūpena paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeyya sampavāreyyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’

segments.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhosanno anādīnavadassāvī anissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
segments.en: They eat that food tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.

segments.pli: So tattha kāmavitakkampi vitakketi, byāpādavitakkampi vitakketi, vihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
segments.en: They think about it with sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.

segments.pli: Evarūpassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dinnaṃ na mahapphalanti vadāmi.
segments.en: A gift to such a mendicant is not very fruitful, I say.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Pamatto hi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu viharati.
segments.en: Because that mendicant is negligent.

segments.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
segments.en: Take another case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā svātanāya bhattena nimanteti.
segments.en: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.

segments.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno, bhikkhave, bhikkhu adhivāseti.
segments.en: The mendicant accepts if they want.

segments.pli: So tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamati; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdati.
segments.en: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāreti.
segments.en: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.

segments.pli: Tassa na evaṃ hoti:
segments.en: It never occurs to them:

segments.pli: ‘sādhu vata myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāretī’ti.
segments.en: ‘It’s so good that the householder or their child serves and satisfies me with their own hands with a variety of delicious foods.’

segments.pli: Evampissa na hoti:
segments.en: They don’t think:

segments.pli: ‘aho vata māyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā āyatimpi evarūpena paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeyya sampavāreyyā’ti.
segments.en: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with a variety of delicious foods in the future, too.’

segments.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ agathito amucchito anajjhosanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
segments.en: They eat that alms-food untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.

segments.pli: So tattha nekkhammavitakkampi vitakketi, abyāpādavitakkampi vitakketi, avihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
segments.en: They think about it with thoughts of renunciation, good will, or harmlessness.

segments.pli: Evarūpassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dinnaṃ mahapphalanti vadāmi.
segments.en: A gift to such a mendicant is very fruitful, I say.

segments.pli: Taṃ kissa hetu?
segments.en: Why is that?

segments.pli: Appamatto hi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu viharatī”ti.
segments.en: Because that mendicant is diligent.”

segments.pli: Paṭhamaṃ.
